awd_titl_txt: CI-ADDO-EN: Scaling, Diversifying and Enriching Planet Lab
awd_abstract_narration: This project is supporting and extending the PlanetLab research testbed. PlanetLab is a 1000-node overlay network spanning  500 sites and 40+ countries world-wide.  It is used to evaluate new network services (e.g., peer-to-peer networks, content distribution, scalable object location services, and adaptive routing overlays), as well as to observe Internet activity (e.g., network topology, routing dynamics, path latency and bandwidth, and failures properties).  In supporting PlanetLab, this project is focused on enabling the research community to add diversity and scale to the set of available computing and communication resources. The project is also extending PlanetLab with improved instrumentation.  Our approach is to leverage the data collection and analysis facilities currently used to operate PlanetLab to provide more value to PlanetLab users. There are two aspects to this. First, the project is making the raw data collected by all tools available for public download.  Of course data can have multiple uses, and it seems likely that the same data used for operations may be of research value to the community.  Second, the project is extending the instrumentation and related toolset to help users answer the kinds of questions they face when developing a widely distributed network service: "Is there something wrong with my service? If so, what is the cause, and how do I fix it?''  Having already made the investment to build a set of efficient data collection facilities and powerful analysis tools, the goal of the project is to see them solve as many problems as possible.

por.por_cntn:
PlanetLab is a global research platform that is used by researchers world-wide to measure the Internet and evaluate new network services. At the conclusion of this award, it supports 1021 users from 197 institutions running active experiments that generate over 4 terabytes of network traffic every day, and over its lifetime, PlanetLab has supported nearly 10000 users from 630 institutions, resulting in hundreds of published research papers.

Researchers use PlanetLab when their experiments require a widely distributed edge presence. This includes probing and measuring the Internet from many vantage points, emulating client workloads on cloud-hosted services, caching data hosted in cloud storage, evaluating the behavior of widely distributed web servers, and experimenting with peer-to-peer applications. In one particularly noteworthy example, Tim Berners Lee and two colleagues at MIT recently used PlanetLab to experiment with HTTPA (HTTP with Accountability), an extension to HTTP that uses Distributed Hash Tables (DHTs) to distribute transaction logs among a set of web servers. HTTPA supports audits that identify all the people who have accessed the data, and does so in a way that assures availability of the logs despite failures, makes it possible to detect tampering. The research demonstrated HTTPA on an example application involving access to health records.

Researchers also use a specialized deployment of PlanetLab, called MeasurementLab (M-Lab), to deploy open source Internet measurement tools. The data collected by those tools is released in the public domain, with the goal of  advancing network research and empowering the public with useful information about their broadband and mobile connections. By enhancing Internet transparency, M-Lab goal is to help sustain a healthy, innovative Internet.

The M-Lab deployment of PlanetLab is global, with over 130 servers across every continent except Antarctica, involves over 35 corporate and governmental partners, supports 16 different performance tools, runs over 200k tests every day, has led to over 25 published researcher papers, and it has been used to collect over a petabyte of measurement data. It provides value to many different stakeholders:

Users – M-Lab provides end-users with the ability to test their broadband and mobile network connections. This gives them real-time performance data about speed, throttling, and blocking, as well as a rich set of diagnostic metrics they can use when communicating with their service providers. Users can also compare performance via interactive broadband maps, thereby making performance data intelligible and meaningful in a global context.

Researchers – M-Lab provides network researchers with access to a state-of-the-art, globally distributed infrastructure that they can use to run rigorous network measurement tests cover vast portions of the globe. They also have access to all the data collected in M-Lab, which is publicly available in its raw form.

Industry – M-Lab is used by industry to gain insight into end-user experiences and to help them diagnose connection problems. Some industrial partners embed M-Lab tools in their applications and services, making access to this measurement data an integrated part of their business strategy.

Regulators and Policymakers – M-Lab provides governmental regulators and policymakers access to objective broadband data. For example, the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has partnered with M-Lab to study broadband coverage and performance data across the major US service providers. Analogous national commissions are conducting similar studies in other countries.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2017
Modified by: Larry L Peterson
